title: Excel Job Track – Portfolio & Interview Prep
videoScript: In this special Excel Job Track lesson, we focus on portfolio projects, hiring assignments, and interview preparation so that you can confidently apply for real-world roles.
blogArticle:
## Excel Job Track – Portfolio & Interview Prep

In this lesson we shift from **features** to **career**.

You will:
- Pick 2–3 portfolio projects and complete them as if they were client work.
- Practice hiring-style assignments that simulate real job tests.
- Prepare for interviews using a structured Q&A bank.
- Organise all your files so they can be shared in job applications.

Treat this as your **launchpad** for MIS Executive, Operations Analyst, Junior Data Analyst or Business Analyst roles.
practiceProblems: Choose one portfolio project (Sales Dashboard, Inventory Management, Attendance & Salary, or Power Query Automation) and complete a 'v1' that you are not embarrassed to show a recruiter.
Write a short, 3-line description of your favourite Excel project as if you were explaining it in an interview.
Organise all your Excel practice files into one clean folder named 'Excel-Portfolio-YourName'.
homework: Complete at least two portfolio projects end-to-end, including documentation inside the workbook.
Ask a friend or classmate to 'play recruiter' and try your files without your help. Fix any confusion they have.
Upload final versions to Google Drive or GitHub and keep the share links ready for job applications.

jobAssignments.title: Portfolio Project – Sales Dashboard
jobAssignments.brief: Create a clean sales dashboard that a small business owner can understand in 30 seconds.
tasks: Use at least one Pivot Table and one regular formula table.
Include 2–3 key KPIs in big, readable numbers (e.g., Total Sales, No. of Orders, Average Order Value).
Add one chart that shows trend over time and one that compares categories.
hints: Imagine the user is busy and opens your file for only half a minute.
Label everything in simple language: 'Sales this month' instead of 'SUM(B2:B200)'.
jobAssignments.hiddenSolution: Use one sheet for raw data and one for the dashboard. Make all summaries refer to Excel Tables. Keep colours minimal and text large. No clutter.

jobAssignments.title: Hiring Assignment Simulation – HR Attendance Sheet
jobAssignments.brief: Simulate a take-home test where the company wants you to fix and finish an HR attendance tracker.
tasks: Implement the rule: If Effective Absent > 3, reduce salary by 20%.
Highlight employees whose Effective Absent > 5 so HR can talk to them.
hints: Use a helper column for Effective Absent using Absent + INT(Late/3).
Wrap final salary formulas in IFERROR if needed.
jobAssignments.hiddenSolution: EffectiveAbsent = Absent + INT(Late/3). FinalSalary = IF(EffectiveAbsent>3, BasicSalary*0.8, BasicSalary). Use conditional formatting on EffectiveAbsent>5.

interviewQA.question: Tell me about an Excel project you are proud of.
interviewQA.hint: Use the structure: Situation → Task → Action → Result.
interviewQA.answer: Example: 'A coaching institute needed a way to track monthly fees and attendance. The manual method in diaries was causing errors. I created an Excel workbook with separate sheets for students, fees and attendance, linked by unique IDs. I used VLOOKUP/XLOOKUP and Pivot Tables to show pending fees and attendance summaries. As a result, fee tracking became faster and they stopped missing follow-ups.'

interviewQA.question: In your opinion, what separates a beginner Excel user from a job-ready Excel user?
interviewQA.hint: Think in terms of reliability and design.
interviewQA.answer: A beginner thinks: 'I can get the answer somehow.' A job-ready user thinks: 'Can others use this file safely next month?' They use Tables, named ranges, clear labels, error handling (IFERROR), and avoid fragile formulas. Their files are readable, not just 'working'.

interviewQA.question: How do you handle missing or inconsistent data in Excel?
interviewQA.answer: I first profile the data using filters, COUNTBLANK and simple Pivot Tables. Then I use tools like Remove Duplicates, Text to Columns, Flash Fill, TRIM, CLEAN and Find & Replace. If something is truly missing, I either request corrected data or mark it clearly instead of guessing. The goal is honest, clean input before analysis.
